blocks.name: basellem1
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ basel . Closure of the sequence of roots. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 30-Jul-2014.) Replace OLD theorem. (Revised ba Wolf Lammen, 18-Sep-2020.)
blocks.origin:
thm basellem1(class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  |- wi(wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))), wcel(co(co(c1, cmul, cpi), cdiv, c2), co(nat0, cioo, co(cpi, cdiv, nat2))))
  -| wceq(c2, co(co(nat2, cmul, c0), caddc, nat1))

  rpgt0d(co(co(c1, cmul, cpi), cdiv, c2), wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))))
  syl2anr(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0)), wcel(co(co(c1, cmul, cpi), cdiv, c2), crp), wcel(co(c1, cmul, cpi), crp), wcel(c2, crp))
  nnrpd(c2, wcel(c0, cn))
  rpdivcl(co(c1, cmul, cpi), c2)
  breqtrd(co(co(c1, cmul, cpi), cdiv, c2), clt, co(cpi, cdiv, nat2), co(co(c1, cmul, cpi), cdiv, co(c1, cmul, nat2)), wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))))
  mpbid(wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))), wbr(co(co(c1, cmul, cpi), cdiv, c2), clt, co(co(c1, cmul, cpi), cdiv, co(c1, cmul, nat2))), wbr(co(c1, cmul, nat2), clt, c2))
  syl6breqr(co(c1, cmul, nat2), clt, c2, co(co(nat2, cmul, c0), caddc, nat1), wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))))
  lelttrd(co(c1, cmul, nat2), co(co(nat2, cmul, c0), caddc, nat1), co(nat2, cmul, c0), wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))))
  syl5eqelr(co(co(nat2, cmul, c0), caddc, nat1), cr, c2, wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))))
  eqbrtrd(co(c1, cmul, nat2), cle, co(nat2, cmul, c0), co(nat2, cmul, c1), wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))))
  sylancl(wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))), wceq(co(c1, cmul, nat2), co(nat2, cmul, c1)), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(nat2, cc))
  2cn()
  mulcom(c1, nat2)
  mpbid(wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))), wbr(co(nat2, cmul, c1), cle, co(nat2, cmul, c0)), wbr(c1, cle, c0))
  adantl(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0)), wbr(c1, cle, c0))
  elfzle2(c1, nat1, c0)
  syl3anc(wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))), wb(wbr(c1, cle, c0), wbr(co(nat2, cmul, c1), cle, co(nat2, cmul, c0))), wcel(c1, cr), wcel(c0, cr), wa(wcel(nat2, cr), wbr(nat0, clt, nat2)))
  adantr(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0)), wcel(c0, cr))
  nnre(c0)
  a1i(wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))), wa(wcel(nat2, cr), wbr(nat0, clt, nat2)))
  pm3.2i(wcel(nat2, cr), wbr(nat0, clt, nat2))
  2re()
  2pos()
  lemul2(c1, c0, nat2)
  ltp1d(co(nat2, cmul, c0), wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))))
  nnred(co(nat2, cmul, c0), wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))))
  adantr(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0)), wcel(co(nat2, cmul, c0), cn))
  syl222anc(wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))), wb(wbr(co(c1, cmul, nat2), clt, c2), wbr(co(co(c1, cmul, cpi), cdiv, c2), clt, co(co(c1, cmul, cpi), cdiv, co(c1, cmul, nat2)))), wcel(co(c1, cmul, nat2), cr), wbr(nat0, clt, co(c1, cmul, nat2)), wcel(c2, cr), wbr(nat0, clt, c2), wcel(co(c1, cmul, cpi), cr), wbr(nat0, clt, co(c1, cmul, cpi)))
  nnred(co(c1, cmul, nat2), wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))))
  nngt0d(co(c1, cmul, nat2), wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))))
  sylancl(wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))), wcel(co(c1, cmul, nat2), cn), wcel(c1, cn), wcel(nat2, cn))
  nnmulcl(c1, nat2)
  nnred(c2, wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))))
  nngt0d(c2, wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))))
  adantr(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0)), wcel(c2, cn))
  syl5eqel(c2, cn, co(co(nat2, cmul, c0), caddc, nat1), wcel(c0, cn))
  peano2nnd(co(nat2, cmul, c0), wcel(c0, cn))
  mpan(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(co(nat2, cmul, c0), cn), wcel(nat2, cn))
  2nn()
  nnmulcl(nat2, c0)
  sylancl(wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))), wcel(co(c1, cmul, cpi), cr), wcel(c1, cr), wcel(cpi, cr))
  nnred(c1, wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))))
  remulcl(c1, cpi)
  rpgt0d(co(c1, cmul, cpi), wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))))
  adantl(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0)), wcel(co(c1, cmul, cpi), crp))
  sylancl(wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0)), wcel(co(c1, cmul, cpi), crp), wcel(c1, crp), wcel(cpi, crp))
  nnrpd(c1, wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0)))
  pirp()
  rpmulcl(c1, cpi)
  ltdiv2(co(c1, cmul, nat2), c2, co(c1, cmul, cpi))
  syl112anc(wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))), wceq(co(co(c1, cmul, cpi), cdiv, co(c1, cmul, nat2)), co(cpi, cdiv, nat2)), wcel(cpi, cc), wa(wcel(nat2, cc), wne(nat2, nat0)), wcel(c1, cc), wne(c1, nat0))
  a1i(wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))), wcel(cpi, cc))
  picn()
  a1i(wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))), wa(wcel(nat2, cc), wne(nat2, nat0)))
  2cnne0()
  nncnd(c1, wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))))
  nnne0d(c1, wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0))))
  adantl(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, co(nat1, cfz, c0)), wcel(c1, cn))
  elfznn(c1, c0)
  divcan5(cpi, nat2, c1)
  mp2an(wb(wcel(co(co(c1, cmul, cpi), cdiv, c2), co(nat0, cioo, co(cpi, cdiv, nat2))), w3a(wcel(co(co(c1, cmul, cpi), cdiv, c2), cr), wbr(nat0, clt, co(co(c1, cmul, cpi), cdiv, c2)), wbr(co(co(c1, cmul, cpi), cdiv, c2), clt, co(cpi, cdiv, nat2)))), wcel(nat0, cxr), wcel(co(cpi, cdiv, nat2), cxr))
  0xr()
  mp2b(wcel(co(cpi, cdiv, nat2), cxr), wcel(cpi, cr), wcel(co(cpi, cdiv, nat2), cr))
  pire()
  rehalfcl(cpi)
  rexr(co(cpi, cdiv, nat2))
  elioo2(nat0, co(cpi, cdiv, nat2), co(co(c1, cmul, cpi), cdiv, c2))

blocks.name: basellem2
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ basel . Show that ` P ` is a polynomial of degree ` M ` , and compute its coefficient function. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 30-Jul-2014.)

blocks.name: basellem3
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ basel . Using the binomial theorem and de Moivre's formula, we have the identity ` _e ^ _i N x / ( sin x ) ^ n = ` ` sum_ m e. ( 0 ... N ) ( N _C m ) ( _i ^ m ) ( cot x ) ^ ( N - m ) ` , so taking imaginary parts yields ` sin ( N x ) / ( sin x ) ^ N = ` ` sum_ j e. ( 0 ... M ) ( N _C 2 j ) ( -u 1 ) ^ ( M - j ) ` ` ( cot x ) ^ ( -u 2 j ) = P ( ( cot x ) ^ 2 ) ` , where ` N = 2 M + 1 ` . (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 30-Jul-2014.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: basellem4
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ basel . By ~ basellem3 , the expression ` P ( ( cot x ) ^ 2 ) = sin ( N x ) / ( sin x ) ^ N ` goes to zero whenever ` x = n _pi / N ` for some ` n e. ( 1 ... M ) ` , so this function enumerates ` M ` distinct roots of a degree- ` M ` polynomial, which must therefore be all the roots by ~ fta1 . (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 28-Jul-2014.)

blocks.name: basellem5
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ basel . Using ~ vieta1 , we can calculate the sum of the roots of ` P ` as the quotient of the top two coefficients, and since the function ` T ` enumerates the roots, we are left with an equation that sums the ` cot ^ 2 ` function at the ` M ` different roots. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 29-Jul-2014.)

blocks.name: basellem6
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ basel . The function ` G ` goes to zero because it is bounded by ` 1 / n ` . (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 28-Jul-2014.)

blocks.name: basellem8
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ basel . The function ` F ` of partial sums of the inverse squares is bounded below by ` J ` and above by ` K ` , obtained by summing the inequality ` cot ^ 2 x <_ 1 / x ^ 2 <_ ` ` csc ^ 2 x = cot ^ 2 x + 1 ` over the ` M ` roots of the polynomial ` P ` , and applying the identity ~ basellem5 . (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 29-Jul-2014.)

blocks.name: basellem9
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ basel . Since by ~ basellem8 ` F ` is bounded by two expressions that tend to ` _pi ^ 2 / 6 ` , ` F ` must also go to ` _pi ^ 2 / 6 ` by the squeeze theorem ~ climsqz . But the series ` F ` is exactly the partial sums of ` k ^ -u 2 ` , so it follows that this is also the value of the infinite sum ` sum_ k e. NN ( k ^ -u 2 ) ` . (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 28-Jul-2014.)

blocks.name: basel
blocks.content: The sum of the inverse squares is ` _pi ^ 2 / 6 ` . This is commonly known as the Basel problem, with the first known proof attributed to Euler. See ~ http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basel_problem . This particular proof approach is due to Cauchy (1821). This is Metamath 100 proof #14. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 30-Jul-2014.)
blocks.origin:
